notesStmt.note: Edward Grier speculates that "the writing suggests a date in the 1850s." (Grier, Edward F., Ed.The Collected Writings of Walt Whitman. Notebooks and Unpublished Manuscripts. 1593).

div1.p: America has been called a proud and arrogant.—It may be, but she does not show i in her criticisms or drama or ^ literature.—^ It is indirect, and therefore more effective Day by day and hou by hour, in tragedy and comedy, in picture and print, in every eimportation of art and literature,letters, she she submits to one ceaselesssteady stretchflow of discrepancy and one supercilious and ceaseless
div1.note: bring in a sockdologer on the Dickens‑fawners

del.ab: speaking best way of king of his graceful and talented school, so numerou th in Great Britain and America.—
del.p: Many of The elevesélèves of this school are graceful talented school are numerous both in Great tain and America, yet we shall speak of their er as the best way of speaking of them. His elevesélèves are perhaps more numerous in New York, in Cincinnati and Charleston than they are in other cities He is the poet of the highly polished graceful and talented writer.—He is the artificial phases of modern societ
